H0.text: converting stereo signal to mono signal is called. Mixing

H1.text: converting stereo signal to mono signal is called. Folding

H2.text: converting stereo signal to mono signal is called. Summing

H3.text: converting stereo signal to mono signal is called. Panning

A4.text: Common examples include downmixing from 5.1 surround sound to stereo, and stereo to mono.

A5.text: The mixdown process converts a program with a multiple-channel configuration into a program with fewer channels.

A6.text: If the two output buses are later recombined into a monaural signal, then a pan law of âˆ’6 dB is desirable.

A7.text: Simple analog pan controls only change relative level; they don't add reverb to replace direct signal, phase changes, modify the spectrum, or change delay timing.
